docs.snippet: There has been a change in the assessment of world economic prospects, clearly reflected in an Aspen Institute conference here. Participants were a high-level group, from government and business in a wide range of countries. Their outlook was so...
docs.lead_paragraph: There has been a change in the assessment of world economic prospects, clearly reflected in an Aspen Institute conference here. Participants were a high-level group, from government and business in a wide range of countries. Their outlook was so gloomy that some American Democrats wondered out loud why candidates in their party were trying so hard to take over responsibility for the Reagan legacy. Remarkably, there was almost complete consensus on what is wrong and what should be done about it - so, little new on diagnosis and prescription. But the shift of mood came from another consensus: that decision makers simply aren't going to take sensible measures until they are forced by crisis. Some of these officials and businessmen have reached a point where they almost hope for crisis, a serious jolt that will oblige leaders to tell the facts of world economic life to the public and to act before the damage is overwhelming.

docs.snippet: A senior Reagan Administration official warned today that the United States would pull out of planned new global trade talks this month unless other nations gave priority to freeing trade in two key areas for the American economy.   The United States...
docs.lead_paragraph: A senior Reagan Administration official warned today that the United States would pull out of planned new global trade talks this month unless other nations gave priority to freeing trade in two key areas for the American economy. The United States Trade Representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said at a news conference here that the two key areas were agricultural goods and services like banking and telecommunications. He said the United States regarded agricultural goods and services as ''priority issues'' for new talks under the General Arrangement on Tariffs and Trade, the world body that regulates commerce. Trade ministers from more than 100 countries hope to begin such negotiations at a meeting in Punta del Este, Uruguay, that starts Sept. 15.

headline.main: U.S. ISSUES THREAT IN TALKS ON TRADE

byline.original: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: PARTLY stymied in his straightforward attempts to reform and modernize the Soviet economy, Mikhail Gorbachev has recently begun to unveil a backdoor strategy. While still in its earliest stages, the plan seems to involve exposing Soviet enterprises...
docs.lead_paragraph: PARTLY stymied in his straightforward attempts to reform and modernize the Soviet economy, Mikhail Gorbachev has recently begun to unveil a backdoor strategy. While still in its earliest stages, the plan seems to involve exposing Soviet enterprises to the international economy through joint ventures with Western companies and through greater Soviet participation in the international economic establishment. By exposing Soviet industry to the ways of the capitalist world, Mr. Gorbachev hopes to stimulate productivity growth and the speedier mastery of world technology. The new policy marks an abrupt break with the past. For years, Soviet authorities have attacked such institutions as the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank as instruments of imperialist and American domination. Now, they have come around to acknowledging the occasional merit of these organizations and hinted that it might be nice if the Soviet Union were allowed to join. Specifically, the Russians have asked for observer status at the GATT meetings, which convene Sept. 15 at Punta del Este, Uruguay.

headline.main: GORBACHEV FINDS AN ALLY IN CAPITALISM

byline.original: By MARSHALL I. GOLDMAN; Marshall I. Goldman, professor of economics at Wellesley College, is author of the forthcoming ''Gorbachev's Challenge: Economic Reform in the Age of High Technology.''

docs.snippet: The Reagan Administration will unblock a stalled agreement allowing United States imports of European steel after being assured that American citrus fruit growers will get better access to European markets, United States trade representative Clayton...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Reagan Administration will unblock a stalled agreement allowing United States imports of European steel after being assured that American citrus fruit growers will get better access to European markets, United States trade representative Clayton K. Yeutter announced here this weekend. After receiving assurances that the 12 European Community countries would ratify another pact giving American citrus fruit and almond growers improved access to their markets, the United States would begin putting into effect, on Sept. 15, the agreement governing imports of European semi-finished steel products worked out last July, Mr. Yeutter said. The Reagan Administration had refused to put into effect the steel agreement after indications that Italy was trying to sabotage the citrus and nut pact, which it believes could hurt its own farmers. But Mr. Yeutter said he is ''totally satisfied'' that the community would ratify the fruit pact ''within the next couple of weeks'' after talks here with European Community Commissioner Willie de Clercq, the chief European trade negotiator.

headline.main: U.S., EUROPE TO SETTLE ON STEEL, CITRUS

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: GENERAL AGREEMENT ON TARIFFS AND TRADE

byline.original: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Latin America's economic recession is ''lengthening dangerously,'' because of huge capital outflows to pay international debt, and will not be reversed until the resource drain is cut ''significantly,'' the Inter-American Development Bank said today....
docs.lead_paragraph: Latin America's economic recession is ''lengthening dangerously,'' because of huge capital outflows to pay international debt, and will not be reversed until the resource drain is cut ''significantly,'' the Inter-American Development Bank said today. In its annual report on ''Economic and Social Progress in Latin America,'' the Washington-based institution, one of the principal multilateral lenders to the region, placed the outflow to pay interest on the debt at nearly $100 billion since the start of the decade. This does not take into account what economists call nonrecorded capital transfers, otherwise known as capital flight, estimated at several times that amount. Grim Data on Crisis The report provided some of the grimmest data to date on the toll the debt crisis is taking on the 23 countries, which together account for two-thirds of the nearly $1 trillion that third world debtors owe foreign creditors.

headline.main: DANGEROUS LENGTHENING OF LATIN RECESSION SEEN

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The United States and France are sharply divided over the timing and extent of any subsidy cuts in agriculture as they prepare for multilateral negotiations next week on a new round of trade liberalization, the United States trade representative,...
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States and France are sharply divided over the timing and extent of any subsidy cuts in agriculture as they prepare for multilateral negotiations next week on a new round of trade liberalization, the United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, said today. Mr. Yeutter said the French were ''very nervous'' about ''fast track'' negotiations in agriculture that the United States wants at the meeting, to be held in Punta del Este, Uruguay. He also said that the question of eliminating all subsidies was ''one of the more contentious issues'' with the French. Mr. Yeutter briefed reporters on preparations for the new round following his meeting last weekend in Lisbon with trade representatives of the European Community, Japan and Canada.

headline.main: FARM AID SPLITS U.S. AND FRANCE

byline.original: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Companies    Coca-Cola will sell 51 percent of its new bottling company to the public in what could be the largest initial stock offering ever. The proceeds are to be used to pay part of the debt from the company's previously announced acquisitions...
docs.lead_paragraph: Companies Coca-Cola will sell 51 percent of its new bottling company to the public in what could be the largest initial stock offering ever. The proceeds are to be used to pay part of the debt from the company's previously announced acquisitions of two of its largest bottlers for a total of $2.4 billion. Allen & Company is expected to be the lead underwriter for the offering, industry sources said. [ Page D1. ] IC Industries will take a $520 million pretax charge as part of a restructuring of its transportation equipment and railroad operations and now expects a net loss for the year. Analysts said the move culminated IC's continuing efforts to reduce the size of its ailing Illinois Central Gulf Railroad. [ D1. ]

docs.snippet: In an effort to bolster the Soviet Union's bid to join the multinational trade talks in Uruguay next week, a senior Soviet trade official pledged today that Moscow would adhere to rules of the 92-member General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade.  ...
docs.lead_paragraph: In an effort to bolster the Soviet Union's bid to join the multinational trade talks in Uruguay next week, a senior Soviet trade official pledged today that Moscow would adhere to rules of the 92-member General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. Mikhail S. Pankine, head of the Department of International Economic Organizations at the Soviet Ministry of Foreign Trade, also said that Russian trade enterprises would ''enjoy increasing autonomy and will be responsible for their business relations with foreign partners'' as part of an ''economic reform'' announced by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, contending that the future of world trade hinges on next week's 92-nation conference in Uruguay, today accused a small group of third world nations of seeking to sabotage those talks.   Mr....
docs.lead_paragraph: The United States trade representative, Clayton K. Yeutter, contending that the future of world trade hinges on next week's 92-nation conference in Uruguay, today accused a small group of third world nations of seeking to sabotage those talks. Mr. Yeutter also told a breakfast meeting of the United States Chamber of Commerce that the United States does not want to walk away from the talks, but may do so if its demands for key agenda items are not met.

docs.snippet: In what Administration officials termed a clear expression of United States frustration, President Reagan warned Brazil's President, Jose Sarney, today that a greater effort must be made to open up that country's markets.   Greeting Mr. Sarney at the...
docs.lead_paragraph: In what Administration officials termed a clear expression of United States frustration, President Reagan warned Brazil's President, Jose Sarney, today that a greater effort must be made to open up that country's markets. Greeting Mr. Sarney at the White House in the first meeting between the two leaders, Mr. Reagan hinted at possible United States retaliation unless Brazil made it easier for American products to compete. ''Trade must be free, and it must be fair,'' Mr. Reagan said at a White House welcoming ceremony. ''And the fight for free trade must start at home.

headline.main: REAGAN WARNS BRAZIL CHIEF ON TRADE
